title: Idea: The move-hunk
description:
I wish Git would show moves on a finer granularity than whole files. Why isn‚Äôt there a diff format that could express that? It‚Äôs not like moving sections of code (also within the same file) isn‚Äôt necessary sometimes.

Motivation:

I‚Äôm looking at a commit that supposedly moves a lot of code from within one set of files to within another set of files. As usual, it also makes necessary changes along the way (that belong in the same commit), which is what I‚Äôm interested in ‚Äì the actual changes.

Looking at this commit is not humanly possible. Let me define that: If, hypothetically, git would show each positive and negative hunk together, you could at least have compared them by sight, and that would have been humanly possible. But instead, it‚Äôs a scattered puzzle, and just beginning to unravel that makes my hand hurt due to the scrolling distances involved. Yes, I‚Äôm physically damaged by the need for scrolling speed, to the point where I can only use vertical mice, and vertical mice that can freewheel don‚Äôt exist for some reason, which is a big problem. So I‚Äôm not looking at the diff. Instead, my approach to situations like this is to iteratively look at the diffstat as the silhouette of probable moves and try to undo them one by one to reduce the problem until it‚Äôs clear what‚Äôs left. The diff is so not a representation of what happened ‚Äì and reading that out of it, so not a job for a mere mortal ‚Äì that it‚Äôs easier to do the work twice to discover what it was.
